Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: This award will help to support student attendance at the 57th IEEE Annual Symposium on the Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS) in New Brunswick, NJ on October 9 through October 11, 2016, as well as to support attendance by some qualified postdoctoral fellows who do not have other sources of travel funding. FOCS and its sister conference, the ACM STOC meeting, are the premier broad-based conferences on the Theory of Computing. FOCS has a record of strongly encouraging participation by students, for whom the conference serves as a valuable educational experience, both for the technical content of the talks and for the opportunities for networking that it provides. In recent years, the annual FOCS conference has been attended by eighty to one hundred students who have comprised more than a third of all attendees. This award will provide partial support to twenty or more students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This proposal was for NSF support to assist students and postdoctoral fellowsfor travel to attend the Annual IEEE Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science (FOCS) 2016 sponsored by the IEEE Computer Society Technical Committee on Mathematical Foundations of Computing. Along with ACM STOC (Symposium on Theory of Computing), IEEE FOCS is one of the two premier annual research conferences that covers the breadth of

theoretical computer science. FOCS 2016, the 57th FOCS, was held in New Brunswick, NJ from October 9-11, 2016.

 

Twenty two applicants were supported, with two of them coming from under-represented groups. Theoretical foundations continue to serve as a backbone of computer science: e.g., for models, algorithms, and impossibility results in Big Data and machine learning. Furthermore, junior researchers such as students and postdocs have always played a strong role in this field. It is anticipated that this funding exposed these awardees to cutting-edge ideas that are relevant to modern computer science and its application areas.In terms of broader impact, this funding encouraged and facilitated the participation of under-represented groups in a top-tier computer science conference; the conference attendees in general also benefited from the greater attendance and consequently higher proportion of students and under-represented groups that this travel grant made possible:


Last Modified: 09/01/2017
Modified by: Aravind Srinivasan
